Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Virtual Microbe: Biophysical Modeling of Morphogenesis

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Regulation of cell shape defined by a cytoskeleton, cell wall, or the extracellular environment is carried out in individual cells and tissues from all biological kingdoms. Robust, accurate bacterial growth requires sophisticated choreography of the cytoskeleton and cell-wall synthesis to control cell shape and maintain structural integrity, as changes in bacterial cell shape have critical consequences for motility, immune system evasion, proliferation, and adhesion. For most bacteria, the cell wall determines cell shape, although the detailed mechanisms of growth and shape maintenance remain elusive. This research will produce a versatile biophysical modeling framework bridging the fundamental principles of cell-shape determination at the molecular and cellular scales. Three critical biological challenges will be addressed: (i) the integration of cytoskeletal mechanics and dynamics with cell-wall growth, (ii) the incorporation of multilayered cell-wall growth to investigate the growth patterns of thick-walled bacteria, and (iii) the elucidation of how cells constrict during division. Each project will interrogate the roles of intracellular spatial organization, mechanical forces, and kinetics to provide theoretical predictions for experimentation. In total, this research aims to discover the simple physical rules that allow cells to achieve robust, shape-preserving growth across kingdoms. This approach should reveal general physical principles of cell growth that fundamentally link the molecular structure of the cytoskeleton, mechanisms of cell-wall synthesis, and the coordination of organismal-scale behavior, empowering the deconstruction of the evolutionary origin of cell shape and tissue polarity.

Broader Impacts: The PI will construct a wiki containing introductory lectures on bacterial morphogenesis available to the microbiology community and other educational institutions worldwide. In addition, the PI will distribute a computational platform for evaluating models of cell-shape determination, and will run an annual workshop on its implementation to aid in development of other models. This software will also serve as a platform for a high-school educational module regarding elastic networks. The PI will continue to pursue elementary-school outreach, undergraduate and graduate education, and campus-wide community building. The PI's core class on the Physical Biology of Cells, the foundation for the new Bioengineering undergraduate major at Stanford, integrates and motivates chemistry, physics, mathematics, and computer science through biological models. The PI's class on Computational Modeling of Microbial Communities (registered jointly in Bioengineering and Microbiology) will utilize project-based learning to motivate the students to employ computational modeling of metagenomics, imaging, and transcriptomics datasets and to disseminate their results. The PI will partner with a nearby group of ethnically and economically diverse fifth graders; the students will collect ecological samples of local microbial communities and visit Stanford to image their samples and to explore the microbial world through hands-on learning. The PI has also demonstrated a commitment to women and students from underprivileged socioeconomic backgrounds, both from Stanford and from neighboring schools in the Bay Area, through mentorship of undergraduates and graduate students and other outreach activities. Collectively, these efforts will achieve considerable progress toward a fundamental understanding of the unexplored frontiers of bacterial morphogenesis and integrate physics and mechanics with traditional microbiological approaches. Moreover, these theoretical approaches have direct applicability to synthetic biology, cellular community design, and the control of bacterial growth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award focused on generating modeling-based predictions of mechanisms by which bacteria determine their shape. Aim 1, modeling the coupling between the cytoskeleton and cell-wall synthesis, was highly successful in generating biophysical models of Gram-negative cell growth that integrate cytoskeletal mechanics and dynamics with cell-wall insertion. Using these models, we addressed how specific spatial patterning of synthesis affects cell-shape maintenance. Our simulations have allowed us to infer right-handed wall ultrastructure in E. coli and revealed a left-handed twist during cell elongation. We also demonstrated that a mutation in the cytoskeletal protein MreB increases cell size and confers a significant fitness advantage, due to accelerated transition between lag phase and rapid growth, and developed a library of cell-size mutants to show that DNA and cytoskeletal concentration are conserved across mutants, and that the curvature-based localization of MreB shifts systematically with cell width. These results underscore the fundamental relationship between cell geometry and fitness.

To interrogate coordination between MreB and the wall, we transiently inhibited cell-wall synthesis in E. coli to generate cell-wall deficient, spherical L-forms, and found that they robustly reverted to a rod-like shape after inhibition cessation. Throughout reversion, MreB localized to inwardly curved regions and targeted wall synthesis to these regions, suggesting that MreB provides the geometric measure to actively establish and regulate morphology. Our coarse-grained mechanochemical models of this reversion process show that curvature-mediated growth is necessary and sufficient for establishing rod-like shape.

 

In Aim 2, biophysical models of Gram-positive growth, we studied growth in the model Gram-positive organism Bacillus subtilis. We found that wall thickness and mechanical strain were maintained even between media that yielded a three-fold change in growth rate. We developed a biophysical model of the Gram-positive wall balancing the mechanical effects of synthesis of new material and removal of old material through hydrolysis. Our results indicate that cells can vary their growth rate while maintaining a constant cell-wall thickness and strain through keeping a constant ratio of synthesis and hydrolysis rates.

            We used osmotic shock to perturb elongation of B. subtilis cells, to probe the feedback mechanisms that regulate wall expansion.  Hypoosmotic shock caused growth oscillations dependent on peptidoglycan synthesis. This behavior can be explained by a simple mathematical theory, whereby growth oscillations are initiated when high mechanical strain in the plasma membrane induces transient growth arrest by inhibiting wall-precursor flux, a mechanism we call “strain inhibition.” 

 

In Aim 3, mechanisms of cell-wall constriction during cell division, we used molecular dynamics simulations to show that polymers of the division protein FtsA exhibited a preferred bending direction that would allow for its placement parallel to FtsZ polymers underneath the cytoplasmic membrane, thereby driving cell constriction. Targeting the mechanisms of action of proteins involved in bacterial cell division bypasses problems associated with increasingly ineffective variants of older antibiotics. To uncover the mechanism of action of the drug PC190723, we examined the structural environment of the binding pocket. Analysis of MD simulations of FtsZ bound to GTP or with PC190723-resistance mutations showed that PC190723 strongly prefers to bind FtsZ in the nucleotide-bound state, and that polymerization may enhance PC190723 binding.

Our experimental studies provided understanding of the connection between cell-wall synthesis and division. Our finding that the division machinery undergoes wall-synthesis-dependent treadmilling suggests a powerful model for robust construction of regularly-shaped poles. Our work has shown that cell division is a particularly sensitive point in the cell cycle due to the potential for defects in the coupling of cell wall growth and membrane synthesis. A dominant mutation in MlaA increases OM permeability, drug sensitivity, and cell death in stationary phase. Single-cell imaging revealed that death occurs after protracted loss of OM material through blebbing at cell division sites, eventually resulting in rupture. Linked to these findings, we have shown that the outer membrane is a major mechanical stabilizer of the cell. Survival of mechanical perturbation was directly dependent on the integrity of the outer membrane.

 

Outreach:

In keeping with the focus of the grant, PI Huang taught courses in a range of subjects that attract students from across the biological sciences and engineering, in which students were taught to develop models of biological systems using physics-based theory and computational analysis. These courses had greater representation from women and minorities than traditional engineering disciplines (~50% female enrollment). In particular, he developed a new project-based course, “Introduction to Computational Modeling of Microbial Ecosystems.” This course addresses the computational training gap by giving the students basic skills that allow them to formulate interests for the future pursuit of independent research; lectures from this class are freely available online. PI Huang is actively involved in K-12 education with a fifth grade class at Independent Elementary School in Castro Valley, CA, an ethnically and economically diverse school. He also mentored numerous high school students, several of which are from diverse backgrounds.
